ygData.subject: Re: [cantera] reaction order
ygData.msgSnippet: Ulf, in general, Cantera allows any kinetics model to be used as long as it is implemented in some C++ class derived from class Kinetics in the Cantera

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=US-ASCII;
	format=flowed

  Ulf,

  in general, Cantera allows any kinetics model to be used as long as it 
is implemented in some C++ class derived from class 'Kinetics' in the  
Cantera kernel.  The 'GasKinetics'  class, used by class 'IdealGasMix', 
implements elementary gas-phase kinetics and  and therefore requires 
that the reaction order equal the stoichiometric coefficient.  On the 
other hand, class 'InterfaceKinetics',  which handles surface and 
interfacial reactions,  does allow global irreversible rate expressions 
with arbitrary reaction orders.  (Interfacial kinetics are not yet 
fully implemented in Cantera, but this class is present in the source 
distribution. )

So basically, if you're working in C++ you can create any kinetics 
model you like with Cantera, but if you are using Cantera from Python 
or Matlab, or are using IdealGasMix, then the forward reaction order 
for each species must equal its reactant stoichiometric coefficient.

As an aside, even though some other software packages allow defining 
reversible reactions  with arbitrary reaction orders,  such reactions 
cannot satisfy the equation of reaction equilibrium, and therefore 
strictly speaking are inconsistent with the laws of thermodynamics.  
But arbitrary reaction  orders are fine in global rate expressions as 
long as the reactions are modeled as irreversible.

Dave G.



On Thursday, March 13, 2003, at 05:24 AM, usenechal wrote:

> Professor,
>
> is it possible to use not the stoichometric coefficients as species-
> reaction order but another value?
>
> e.g.
> Species: A B
> Reaction:  1 A -> 1 B
> Rate of change of Species A: dC(A)/dt=-k*C(A)^x
>
> Normally x is set to the stoichometric coefficient (1 in this
> example), can I change this to an arbitrary number?
>
> best regards
> Ulf Senechal
>
>

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Type: text/enriched;
	charset=US-ASCII

 Ulf,


 in general, Cantera allows any kinetics model to be used as long as
it is implemented in some C++ class derived from class 'Kinetics' in
the  Cantera kernel.  The 'GasKinetics'  class, used by class
'IdealGasMix', implements elementary gas-phase kinetics and  and
therefore requires that the reaction order equal the stoichiometric
coefficient.  On the other hand, class 'InterfaceKinetics',  which
handles surface and interfacial reactions,  does allow global
irreversible rate expressions with arbitrary reaction orders. 
(Interfacial kinetics are not yet fully implemented in Cantera, but
this class is present in the source distribution. ) 


So basically, if you're working in C++ you can create any kinetics
model you like with Cantera, but if you are using Cantera from Python
or Matlab, or are using IdealGasMix, then the forward reaction order
for each species must equal its reactant stoichiometric coefficient.


As an aside, even though some other software packages allow defining
<italic>reversible</italic> reactions  with arbitrary reaction orders, 
such reactions cannot satisfy the equation of reaction equilibrium,
and therefore strictly speaking are inconsistent with the laws of
thermodynamics.  But arbitrary reaction  orders are fine in global
rate expressions as long as the reactions are modeled as irreversible.


Dave G.




On Thursday, March 13, 2003, at 05:24 AM, usenechal wrote:


<excerpt>Professor,


is it possible to use not the stoichometric coefficients as species-

reaction order but another value? 


e.g. 

Species: A B

Reaction:  1 A -> 1 B

Rate of change of Species A: dC(A)/dt=-k*C(A)^x


Normally x is set to the stoichometric coefficient (1 in this 

example), can I change this to an arbitrary number?


best regards

Ulf Senechal
